div.head: ISOLATION ?
div.p: The isolation of Germany was proclaimed a year ago from the housetops, and the isolated Empire continue? to make head diplomatically against the combined Powers of the West "The Kaiser has shown his hand too soon," say some of his critics; "he holds no trumps," say others, but he has already scored his points despite all the critics in the world and he may score still farther before the hand is played out.

Protests without number have been made against the Moroocan policy of the German Empire, or the German Emperor, for in German foreign politics "L'dtat c'eet moi" with a vengeance. The British and French Press have described it as perfidious, execrable, mean, damnable, and intriguing. With more than feminine sentimentalism our leader-writers have dilated on the perversity with which the German Empire has attempted to sow discord between friendly and allied Powers, has expatiated on the perils which encompass it—fines for the disturbance of the peace—and bar lamented the deterioration of German pditica morality and the growing arrogance of German olaims, while it barks .the question whether suoh a thing as political morality can be laid tc exist at all, muchh less to govern the international relations of the various Powers of the modern world.

Since the days of the Great Elector the policy of the North German statesmen has never changed, and it is by the Northerner that the German Empire is ruled to-day. The German's one ideal is the greatness of his country, 18th century Prussia or the Empire of the present day, and unlike certain of his rivals he is prepared to do more than talk for his country's greatness. He has turned his back on the artistic cosmopolitanism that once made the petty States of south and central Germany so attractively, so engagingly help leer, for a narrow and hard but disciplined nationalism bearing as its motto, "If other races stand in my way—well,so much the worse for the other races." He bears the burdens of military service and of a seven State discipline without wincing, and to-day be reaps the profits of a century of self-abnegation and toil. Had any other Government protested against the Anglo French Agreement relative to Morocco, and demanded a European Conference, it would have been laughed down by the world, and had it persisted the French armies and the British fleets would have made ready for battle, but when Germany spoke the Powers grumbled, played with their swordhilts—and went to Algeciras, for they knew they had a redoubtable opponent with whom to deal and that boarhounds and similar large dogs of a surly and cantankerous breed can bite as well as bark.

So far Germany has gained, and gained at all points. She has brought the Powers to the Conference she has dismissed M. Delossé, she has made it certain that France will not have that free hand in Morocco for which she abandoned her policy of opposition to the British control of Egypt, and she has done something, however little, to weaken the Anglo- French Entente, for when the French people, recovering from the smart what they regard as an insult, realise that Morocco may never be theirs - unless they pay a heavy price or risk hopeless overthrow then the Entente will be tested and we shall see what all the dinners and junketings are really worth. Again, Germany has done something to gain the support of Islam : she has posed as its patron, and the Saltan of Morocco and of Turkey have cause to believe in her friendliness—for the present. She has perhaps secured an ally in Turkey, Austria supports her with misgivings at the Conference, and may sopport her in the conflict that perhaps will follow the futile sittings at Algeciras. She does not love the German, she knows that the German Empire may one day absorb her, but she knows too - that if that Empire falls there are other foes who will rend her in pieces. The German-Austrian will probably prefer, if he has any choice in the matter, to be swallowed by his unpopular kinsman than to be rent in pieces by a mixed multitude of Roumanians and Magyars, Italians and Slavs.

But we shall still go on speaking of Germany's isolation—though if these are the fruits of isolation we may thank Heaven that Germany has no very ardent allies. And the moral is that if you are efficient and pushful, you will often get your way.

div.head: S M S Lorelay,
div.p: The German despatch boat Loroely (Captain voh Kroeigk) arrived at Alexandria on Satur- day from Constantinople on a cruise in the Levant.

div.head: American Deserters.
div.p: Quite a number of sailors have deserted from the American Squadron now at Alexandria. There is a reward of £2 for anyone securing a deserter and getting him aboard.

div.head: Playing with Fire.
div.p: 'A native girl of ten was playing with matches when her dress caught fire and caused her serious burns. She was taken to hospital a precarious condition.

div.head: Lord Cromer's Report.
div.p: We are informed that Lord Cromer's Report for the past year will probably not be in the hands of the public much before the end of next month.

div.head: ftew Khedivial Hotel.
div.p: Owing to the hall to be given to-morrow evening in. aid of the Fonidlings' Home, persons wishing to dine at the New Khedivial Hotel are requested to order their tables beforehand.

div.head: Karr el-Aly.
div.p: Prince Ahmed Pacha Kamal has, says a native contemporary, recently sold his share in the Kasar l-Aly estate at Cairo for the sum of L.E 750,000. The share of Prince Mohamed Bey Ibrahim io the same estate was previously sold for LE. 180,000.

div.head: English Printing In Egypt.
div.p: Messrs. Wsterlow Bros, and Latyton, Ltd., the well-known London printer, having considerably extended their buisness in Alexandria, have enlarged their factory at Menayer and are opening offices in the Boulevard de Ram'eh. They are also sequiring an office in Cairo.

div.head: Alexandria Constanxa Line.
div.p: The general arrangements of the new Roumanian service between Alexandria and Constanta have been settled by M. Boeresco, the Inspector Gentral of the Roumanian Maritime Service, who has recently been paying a visit to Alexandria in connection with the work of organi- sation of the line. He has now returned to Conatanza.

div.head: No. 3 Palace.
div.p: No. 3 Palace, the Alexandria residence of the Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, situated at Hadra, which was purchased ten yean ago by Ghati Mnkhtar Pacha from H.H. Prince Mohamed Aly for th» torn of L.E. 6,500, and which latterly became the property of tho Turkish Government, has been gifted by the Saltan to Mnkhtar Paoha. His Excellency has, as a mark of gratitude, presented a sum of LE. 10,000 for the Hedjaz Railway. The present value of No. 3 Palace it estimated at L.E. 120,000.
Jewish Choral. Society.

A charming conoert wte given last night by the Jewish Choral Society of Alexandria in the ball-room of the New Khedivial Hotel. The society, which has only been in existence tor a few years, has become one of the most efficient choral societies in Egypt. The members of the soeiety sang four pieces with great success. Miss G Capozzo and Maedamas Calistti and Bounici were much applauded. One of the most delightful pieces rendered was Saint Sacčus' trio for the violon, 'cello and piano from Samson and Delilah, given by Professors Borghesi and Lanzoni. The Governor of Alexandria and a large and fashionable audience were present
Ramleh's Home of Rest,

The following is an extract from a letter to the "Sphinx" from Mrs. Freeman, who is so much interested in philanthropic work both at home and here in Egypt: - "Many of your roaders may be glad to hear of an undertaking just started in Ramleh, near Alexandria,which will conduce to the rest and comfort of many weary workers all over Egypt, who are unable to go home or to Europe for their much needed rest. Four years ago Miss Van Sommer bought a piece of groaod overlooking the and built there a Home of Rest for English missionaries end workers. Till then there had been nothing of the sort for the English in Egypt, and I think that many of our country people who have spent their winter in Egypt; might like to send a little help to further this effort for the comfort and rest of these who work all the year round in the heat of the day for the good of the country and the furtherance of Christianity. Any gift may be sent to Miss Van Sommer, Fair Haven Account, Anglo- Egyptian Bank, Alexandria."
Spend your Holidays at Mena.
The management of Mena Hoose Hotel has arranged special terms for residents of Cairo, Alexandria, and country from the 10th of April to the 10th of May. [ Advt.]

div.head:
AMERICAN SQUADRON.
BANQUET AT ABDEBN PALACE
div.p: H H. the Khedive gave a banquet at Abdeen Palace on Saturday evening in hononr of Rear-Admiral Sigsbee and the officers of the Amerioan Squad on now in Alexandria harboor. The Khedive presided and the guests numbered forty, among them being Rear-Admiral Sigsbee, the Hon. L. M. Iddings, Ameriosn Diplomatic Agent and Consul General,and Mrs. Iddings, Mr. and Mrs. Grew, Judge Tack, Mr. and Mrs. Leigh Hunt, Mr. and Mrs. Bacon, Capt. Nazro. Commander Cutler, Commander Smith, Lt Commander Holmes, Surgeon Odell, Asst. Surgeon Belknap, Lieut. Trant, Paymaster Heap, Lieuts. McCauley, Landis, Lackey end Lewis; Ensigns Andrews and Loomis; Midship man Wickerham, and Midshipman James. His Highness received his guests in a moat hospitable manner, and the dinner was of the most sumptuous description. His Highness's private band discoursed a selection of music during the evening, the programme including several southern negro' melodies, which were remarkably well rendered and most enthusiastically received.
After dinner the naval officers attended the Savoy small dance.
Admiral Sigsbee and his staff lunched with Consul General and Mrs. Iddings yesterday, returning to Alexardria in the afternoon.
This evening Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield is giving a dinner to the Admiral and officers at the New Khedivial Hotel.
Admiral Sigsbee will give a large dinner party on board the Brooklyn in the middle of the week.
Two of tho cruisers of the equadron, the Galveston and tho Chattanooga, leave today for the Par Eut.

div.head: AUSTRO-HUNGARIAN SQUADRON.
div.p: The Austro-Hungarian Squadron will probably remain at Alexandria until tho 11th April.

The ball which is to be given next week on board the Habsburg and the St. George is to be a magnificent affair. These two ironclads are to be drawn op alongside each other in order to form one series of ballrooms, reception rooms, and buffets for the guests.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive gave audience on Friday to Mgr. Porpbyros, Bishop of Sinai, Prince Kamel el Din, Mr. Gibson, and the Rev. Mr. Kaufmann.
On Saturday the Khedive gave audience to tho Ministers, Yacoub Pacha Artin, Mr. Edouard Naville, and Mr. Grubb.
On Saturday evening the banquet in honour of Admiral Sigsbee and the officers of the American Squadron took place at Abdeen Palace.

div.head: THE NEW ''ADVISER."
div.p: Dr. Dunlop's appointment as Adviser to the Ministry of Pablic Instruction arouses excited and furious comments on the part of the Anglophobe vernacular Press, who consider it as a rejoinder to the recent strikes in the Government schools.

div.head: A CANARD.
div.p: Some of our Cairo confréres have recently published a statement lo the effect that a consession had been granted to a syndicate for the erection of telephone lines to connect Port Said with several towns of the interior. The news is manifestly incorrect since the telephone system already existing in Port Said and Zagazig (as well as Suez) belongs to the Telephone Company of Egypt, and should such lines as the local papers mention be erected by the Government Telegraph Department the company in question would have the preference, so that no syndicate is likely to be given a new conceusion until its refusal by the existing Telephone Company, which, we understand, is not the case.

div.head: ANOTHER EGYPTIAN MINING ISSUE.
div.p: Mr. Tyudale White, who presided at the meeting of the Egyptian Mines Exploration last week, said that the company had steadily opened up what the board believed would prove a rich mining area. They had proved the value of the Um Ros Mine, which had passed from the status of a prospect to that of a crushing mine. The company had, however, suffered, as all pioneers suffered, from the heavy expenses incidental to the eatablishment of a now industry, end the business had increased so rapidly that it would require new capital. They had spent about £40 000 in five years, and the subsidiary companies £47,000 more. Generally they were slowly advancing from the exploratory stage to that of valuable gold mines. Though living through bad times, as far as markets were concerned, the result of the developments had left little to be desired, and if times were normal no doubt they would be able to dispose of the company's properties on terms which would show handsome profits. Mining in Egypt as likely to produce satisfactory profits as in any other part of the world, and be confidently recommended them to take shares in them company which he hoped would be shortly brought before them. The company had unitsued shares and other means of raising money for its own purposes, but the heavy expenditure on the three mines must be undertaken by a separate company.

div.head: FRONTIER DISPUTE. SITUATION AT TABAH UNCHANGED. REPORT QF THREATENED BOMBARDMENT DENIED.

div.p: The ' Daily Telegraph's" correspondent at Constantinople reports that the situation at Tabah is unchanged. The British Embassy at Constantinople, on behalf of Egypt, has requested the Turks to leave. Any further action will emanate from the Foreign Office and Egypt.
London, Monday.
This morning new concerning the Akaba incident is without foundation. (Reuter)

We are officially informed that the statements contained in the Reuter's telegram from London and the Havas telegram from Constantinople, to be found in another colomn, are entirely inoorrect so far as regards the bombardment of Akaba.
We are authorised to state that the negotiations between the Egyptian Government and the Sublime Ottoman Porte are still in progress, and that the reply of the Porte is now being awaited.
H.H.S. Aida sailed for Akaba yesterday with stores and despatches for H.M.S. Diana.
H.M.S Hogue arrived at Suez from the South, end entered the Canal yesterday.

div.head:
THE ROYAL VISIT.
ARRANGEMENTS AT SUEZ.
div.p: (From our Correspondents).
Suez, Sunday.
H.M.S. Renown sailed from Aden yesterday afternoon, and is due to arrive at Suez next Wednesday evening.

T. R. H. the Prince and Princess of Wales will land on Thursday forenoon at the Dock station, where preparations are now being made for their reception. H.H. the Khedive's train will be in readiness at the docks to convey the distinguished visitors to Cairo. All trains will be stopped en route in order that the special train may be able to have a run to Cairo.

div.head: THB PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: Suez, Sunday.
The Khodivial mail liner Fayoum arrived at Suez this morning from Tor with a considerable number of Egyptian pilgrims.

div.head: THB SUCRERIES.
div.p: It it reported, thoogh unofficially confirmed, that the Parquet will prosecute the conseil d'administarion of the Sucreries Company.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GOUVERNORAT.
div.p: H E. Mahmoud Pacha Sidky ceased to be Governor of Alexandria yesterday, and will leave for Cairo to take up his new post on Friday next His successor, H.E. Mustapha Pacha Ibady, will not leave Suez for Alexandria until after the arrival of the Prince and Princess of Wales at Suez.

div.head: PENNY POSTAGE.
div.p: Sierra Leone, Jamaica. Somaliland. Gold Coast, Lagos, Barbados, Hong Kong, Ceylon, Falkland Islands, St. Helen, and Mauritius.

div.head:
National Bank of Egypt.
REPORT OF DIRECTORS
div.p: The report of the directors presented to the sixth ordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the National Bank of Egypt, held in Cairo on Saturday last, shows that during the year ouding tbo 31st December, 1905, a grow profit was raised of £408.902.10.8, of which 81.724.2.10, derived from special investments, are exceptional profits. Deducting rebate of interest, £27,418.14.9, and the current expenses, £84,906 5.9, there remains a net profit of £296,577 9.9. The following distribution is laid down by the statutes of the Bank : 4 % to the capital, or 8s. per share, £100,000. 10 % of the net profit to the reserve fund, £29,657.15. 10% to the directors, £16,691.19 6, leaving a balance of £150,227.15 8, to which must be added the balance carried forward last year. £80.417.81, making a total of £180,675.3.4. The directors recommend the payment of a dividend of an additional 8s. per share, which will absorb £100,000 and leave £80,675.8.4. They farther recommend that a sum of £50,000, to be taken from the exceptional profits referred to above, be carried to a reserve fund to be employed specially for equalising future dividends and that £30,675.8.4 be carried forward to profit and loss new account. Each share will thus be entitled to 16s, equivalent to 8 per cent. on the capital.

The Mom liner rabe sailed yesterday aftarooon for Nioolaief in ballast.
The Moss liner Marie arrived here on Saturday afternoon from Barry with a cargo of ooal.

div.head:
CAIRO FLOWER SHOW.
OPENED BY KHEDIVE.
div.p: FAVOURED BY FINE WEATHER.

The Spring Show given by the Kbelivial Horticultural Society was opened on Saturday afternoon at three o'clock by H.H. the Khedive, who arrived punctually at that hour. Perfect weather favoured the occasion, and though some of tha exhibits showed signs of weariness before the afternoon area over, the genial warmth was much appreciated by the visitors. Lord and Lady Cromer arrived early on the scane, the latter looking very well in a gown of light fawn cloth outlined with a narrow trimming of blue and black, and among others ready to recieve his Highness were the Sirdar, Sir Reginald Wiogata, and Lady Wingate, Mr. Machell, Lady Velda Machall, in a pretty gown of thio black lace over pale blue, with touches of pink in the lace vest, M. and Mme Villebois, the latter in dark blue, Crookahank Pacha, Mrs. Crook shank, wearing cream with heavy lace insertions, Capt. the Hon. C. James and Mrs James, Mr. Iddinga and his young daughter in white, Mr. and Mrs. Foaden. the latter wearing dark blue, and Lord Edward Cecil.
The Khedive's Arrival.

His Highness who was met at the enterance by Dr. Keatings, made the tour of the building and the tents in the company of Lady Cromer and appeared mnch interested in all the various exhibits of plants, flowers, and vegetables; and by 3.30 the rest of the world were admitted to follow in his footsteps. Mr. and Mrs. George Royle were there, the latter in a long white surge coat and skirt, and with them came Mrs. Maclean in a dark blue suit, Mr. and Mrs. Allen Joseph cams early, as did Mr. and Mrs. Satow, Mrs. Satow wearing a pretty soft shade of blue with deep points of heavy lace upon the bodice. Mrs. Madden,who was accompanied by her children, was in blue mus'in, and Miss Phillips, wearing heliotrope, was with Dr. and Mrs Phillips. Lady Willcocks was with friends, and Sir Horace and Lady Pinching were dutifully doing the rounds. Lady Pinehing wearing a costume of pale fawn with narrow bands of paune of a deeper shade, and a vary pretty Sèvre blue hat Miss Gordon Soott was in cream voile with lace corsage and her wide-spreading hat was of russet coloured chiffon and lace with a big bunch of white plumes. The Miles de Villaboii, who were among those present at tha arrival of the Effeodina, were in soft silks of palest amber and had on hats of Tascan straw flower bedecked, and both Mrs. Carton de Wiart and Miss James wire in dainty grey toilettes Sir Malcolm and Lady Mellwraith were present, the latter in cream with blue sash and a big blue veil floating around her hat and Mrs. Graham looked very well in a soft shade of green voile with fine lace about the shoulders. Col. and Mrs. Matchett Bay were oresent as were also Mrs. Matchett Innes, Mrs. Reid. Mrs. Knight, Boghos Pacha Nubar and Mile Nuba, M. and Mme. Maskens. Bonuteau Bay, and many others.

flowers scattered over them. Mrs. Maclean won also the first prize for her dejsuner table, which was effectively decorated with daffodils and gypeophilia is silver bowl and vases, and Mrs. Royle was awarded second prize for her table upon which appeared a very handsome array of scarlet poppies and green grasses in silver vases. There were many who admired Mrs H. Garney Sheppard's table, which were decorated with nutrients end gysophilia, and Mrs. Chakourhad arranged a very effaotive design in white and yellow may. Mr. Stamm bad contributed a vary handsome table hors concours with a high centre piece filled with long branches of pink roses trails ol roses connected with green ribbon lying on the cloth.
Cut Flowers.

There were two first prises for the beat arrangement of out flowers in vases. Mrs. Carton de Wiart won hers with every handsome high vase filled with masses of bankeia roses, and Miss Reid had the most gorgeous collection of La Prance roses in a bowl. The second prize went to Mrs H. Wilson, who had filled a low vase with a handsome group of pink and yellow roses, and Mrs. Sheppard was awarded an honourable mention for the most artistic arrangement of wild flowers from Mariout in a tall, slander silver vase.

Mra Carton do Wiart likewise won the first priM for tha beet a too rated basket of thwers, with a beautiful green basket filled with deep orimaoe rorev. The eeoond prin in this class went to Misi Crewe, who had fi'led ber basket with roMi and may. Much credit is also due to the baskets decorated by various native gardeners and others, some of which were esoeedingiy elegant.
Model Garden.

Native ingenuity was also responsible for the wonderful model garden and house which was exhibited in the centre of the building. The little house and lodges were of wood, painted white and gold, and many lighted lamps decorated hot boildings and garden walls, wonderful artificial flowers appeared in the flower beds, and a life sized canary kept guard by the front door, and a gaily colored paved pathway meandered at great length from gate to gate.

The vegetables, fruits, etc., ware exhibited in an adjoining teat, but whatever their intrinsic value their artiatio merits do not for special mention in these columns. A seductive array of jams, preserved fruits, end syrups of all kinds claimed the attention of the domestically inclined, and the good house-wife found much to hanker after in the other exhibits, But to the general ran of visitors the excellent tea-tent hard bye held irreristable attractions.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Among the pasengers who left by the Austrian mail on Saturday were Prince von Liohtchendtein, Princess Radiivill, Counters Oynhausen and daughter, Conotoss Hawerdin, Baron Bruckmann, Count and Countess de Kuenberg, Capt. Grogan, Capt. Powell, etc.
Mahmoud Pacha Sidky, accompanied by Beneducci Bey, paid a visit this morning to the commandant of the German despatch-boat Lorely.

The death is announced at Omdurman, of El Miralai El-Nur Bay Mohamed, so well known in the recent history of the Sudan. El Nur Bey, it will be remembered, was commandant of the troops at Senuar, which he valiantly defended when the Mahdi's influence was rising and eclipsing that the Egyptian Government. His name will always remain engraved in the history of the Sudan as that of a loyal and brave soldier.
Judge and Mrs. Alaton gave a dinner of 14 covers at Mens House Hotel yesterday evening.
The names of Col. Maberly, D.S.O., and od Major Owen were omitted from the list of the hosts in our account of the recent Bachelors' Ball.

Mr. and Mrs. Lamplough are leaving Cario for England on the 31st, and Mr. Lamplough takes back with him many an inspiration for his exhibition of sketches to be held in London during the early summer. It is much to be regretted that Mr. and Mrs. Lamplough have finished their season here under very sad circumstances. It was only a few days ago that they received a cable from home announcing the sad fact of the death of their baby daughter whom they had left with relatives less than three months ago. The Symmpathu of all their friends is with them in their bereavement.

The following Army officers have been granted leave of absence, on private affairs:- Lieut. B.A.P. Schreiber, 20th Hussars (adjt. M.M.P.), Major C. A. Wilding, Capt. S.J. Somerville, Capt. R. Blackett, Lieut. W.E. Rothwell 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers; Capt. and Brevet Major H.M. Finch and 2nd Lieut. J.R. Robertson, 2nd Royal Barks. Regt; Rev. F.I. Anderson, C.F. The later has permission to travel in Italy, Switzerland, France, and Great Britain.
A marriage has been arranged between Mr. John Schilizzi and Miss Helen Lounghis, both of this city.
The marriage of Mr. John H. Burton to Miss Mary Smith will take on Wednesday April 18.

div.head:
ENGLAND AND TURKEY.
THREAT OF BOMBARDMENT.

div.p: The Porte insists that Tabsh is an integral part of tha Ottoman Empire and belongs to the district of Akabt. The Turkish military authorities are erecting posts to demarcate the boundary of the Sinai Peninsula.

Great Britain has replied to Turkeys refusal to withdraw the troops from Tabeli. Britain is unable to accept the Turkish view and expresses the hope that the Porte will reconsider its position ; meanwhile the cruiser Diana remains in the vicinity. (Beultr)

It is expocted that an ultimatum will be sent to the Turkish commander at Akabe requiring the withdrawal of his troops from Tabah within 24 hours. Failing compliance his position will be bombarded, but it is possible that the Ports will yield at the last moment. (Reuter)
It is believed that an ultimatam will be sent to the commandant at Akabe to withdraw his troops, otherwise the British cruiser will bombard. (Hacas)
The dissatisfaction in the German Press regarding the conduct of the German case at Algeciras is growing. Count von Bhalow's position is seriously discussed. ( Reuter)
It is probably a definite agreement will be come to tomorrow.
(Havas)
It is believed that the Government will make Count Lamsdorff's lettar an osoasion for retiring from an untenable position. (Reuter)
The elections for tha National Assembly are proceeding but the majority of voters are refraining from participating, though the Jews are most adtive and are scoring successes in Lithuania. (Reuter)

div.head:
RUSSIAN INTERNATIONAL DISORDERS.
THE DEATH ROLL

div.p: The Government returns show that 14,130 persons were killed and 19,524 wounded during the international disorders in 1905. The Press believes that these figures have been minimised. (Reuter)
Russia is itroducing an income tax. (P.)
It is reported here that two Japanese merchant sailors have been arrested in a fort at Viasivostok. Plans and notes were found on them. (Reuter)
The battelship Wisconsin, with urgent orders, will sail at midnight in order to jolt the American fleet at Shanghai. (Reuters)
King AIfoso has embarked for the Canarios. (Haves)
The Cosnoil of Ministers has fixed on May 6 as the date of the legislative elections. (H)
It has been decided to make a referendum among the miners on the 28th inst. (Havas)
The port has sent delegates to the Portal Congress at Rome against the recognition of the foreign post offices in Turkey. (Havas)

div.head:
THE EDUCATION BILL
PROLONGED SETTING OF CABINET.

div.p: A prolonged sitting of tho Cabinet took place yesterday. The Education Bill wat disscused.
Mr. Birrel, President of the Board of Education, will receive a Catbolio deputation on the 29th instant. (Reuter)
Lord Halifax moves in the Hoose of Lords on the 29th instant that the House desires to regard its high apprecciation of Lord Milner's services in South Afrioa. (Reuter)
The South African commisiioners will sail on the 7th April. (Reuter)
Indian experts are, of opinion that it would be impossible to obtain Indians for South Africa owing to the Indian demand for labour. (Reuter)
The Prince and Princess of Wales and the Duke and Duchess of Connauglit have arrived here. (Reuter)
The Duke and Duchess of Connaught landed here and launched at the British Residency. They unveiled the statue of Queen Victoria and sailed in the evening. (Reuter )
Mr. Haldane has ordered an enquiry to be held regarding the reguarding of the circumstances of Liouteoant Clark Kennedy of the Guards at Aldershot, who fled to London, hie nerves being ahattered,

The Reichstag has adopted the Budget Committee's reccomendation of striking out 15,250,00 marks on behalf of the reinforcements in Damstaland. The Committee urged the necessity for the troops returning home as soon as possible.
The Reichstag also rejected a demand to grant 4,000,000 for the Windhoek Rehoboth railway. (Reuter)
Athletic Sports. Oxford beat Cainbridge by 7 to 3 events. (Reuter)

div.head: "THE NILE QUEST"
div.p: The history of the long search for the sources of the Nile is one of the most facenating stories of discovery, for it begins offline antiquity end only emit in the present day Sir Harry Johnson is the author of this boll which is the first of a series dealing with thsi exploration of the lands and seas, and he had written a most intensely interesting book which should appeal especially to the inhababitants of this country, for Egypt, as Herodotus long ago noted, is "the gift of the Nile." The dawn of Nile exploration begins with the early histroy of Egypt, and the solution of the great secret was attempted by Greeks, Abyssinians, Jews, Islamites, Italians, and Portaguese, who handed on the unsolved riddle to English, French, and German. Even now the Duke of the Abrozzi is fitting out an expedition to explore the mysterious Mountains of the Moon, which form the waterhead between the Nile and the Congo, and are situated at the head waters of the White Nile. Sir Harry writes in an easy and a pleasant style, which conceals the great amount of research which the compilation must have cost him. We cordially recommend the work to our readers. It is published by Alston Rivers, Limited, of London, end the cost is 7s. 6d.

div.head: DOCTOR'S DICTA.
div.p: STRONG COMMENTS ON TEA DRINKING.

Dr. Rigby, a medical practitioner, of Preston, has made a vigorous onslaught on the teetotalers of the town, who, he says, attack the licensed victualler in season and out of season, denying him the barest elements of justice, while on two evils even graver than drink, the abuse of tea and tobacoo, they are silent.

"I firmly believe," says the doctor, "that the moderate and reasonable use of beer as a beverage is less harmful than the same use of tea, and that immodorate tea drinking causes more pain, suffering, ill health, and nervous break down than the excessive consumption of beer. If a man takes too much tea the results are quite as deadly. If he takes too much tea the results are quite as deadly, even more so, but as they are insidious, and not generally apparent they are put down to some other cause.

"To encomerate the diseases caused by tea is like writing a quack advertisment. It produces anemia, chronic gestritis, dyspepsia, and emaciation ; lays the foundation for gastric ulser; causes irritability to the nerves, and a whole host of nervous disorders. If any one were desirous of amassing a fortune, no surer plan of doing so could be devised than to make up pills of innocent materials, such as breadorumbs and extract of hops, and, in the directions for their use by the public, atipulate that the patient should abatain from the use of tea. The pill would have an enormous sale,would do a vast amount of good, and would relieve a great ammount of suffering. In fact, it would , I believe, prove more beneficial than the o'oring half the public houses in Preston."
For all these reasons Dr. Rigby advises the teetotalers to refrain from their favorite pursuit of baiting the "Trade," and to take action regarding the use of tea and tobacco.

div.head: EXCAVATIONS IN THE DELTA.
div.p: The Temple Of Onias.

A correspondent of the Times" has supplied an instructive account of the excavations undertaken during this season by the British School of Archeaology in Egypt on the eastern side of the Delta and in the region of Goshen and Soccoth, which will empplement the interesting details kindly applied us by Professor Plinden Petrie, which we publishes on the inst.

Among the problème there, says the writer, fine of the most interesting was the dearch for the site of the temple of Onias. It is well known how the troubles of the Jews under Antiochus has driven many of them to settle in the east of ths Delta, and that, in order provide a new rallying point, one of the family of the high priests Onies IV., had built a temple on the model of that at Jerusalem. This temple served as a substitue for the shrine decorated and polluted" by Antiochus Epi- phanes. The documents quoted by Joaephus show that this temple was at the site of an old Egyptian town named Leontopolia, which was dedicated to the lion-headed goddess "Bubestis of the fields," that the place was "full' of materials," that the temple was built after the pattern of that at Jerusalem, that "a tower of stone 60 cubits high" was erected, and that the whole settlement was granted by Ptolemy Philometor. That there were many conditons to be fulfilled in the identification of this site.

It has been generally recognized that the ancient town known as Tell el Yehndiyeh, 18 miles north of Cairo:, was probably the position; and the Jewish grave stores found there by Dr. Neville had given strength to thie opinion, But the temple had not yet been actually identified. The work of this season has in the first place shown that a lion goddess was worshipped there, as a statue of an admiral of the Mediterranean fleet of Psametek II. was found which represents him holding a shrine of the lion-headed geddess Hence the name of Leontopolis and the dedication to "Bubastis of the fields" accord with the worship at this site. The description of the place at being "full of material's" for ruse by Oniss agrées with there baring been an immense stone-lined ditch a mile in length around the ancient town, which would apply material for the new building without what bad been consecratol to idols. Just outside of the ancient town stands an artificial mound, the highest for 20 or 30 miles around. The whole of it has been thrown up at one time and, on restoring the buildings on it by the remaining indications, it is found that the height most have been altogether over 59 Greek cobite above the plaio, aereeing with that 60 cobitt of construction-named by Josephus. And this mound was thrown up in the second century B.C, as is shown by the pottery in it. On the top were many coins of the time of Ptolemy Phifometor, end a1 she'd with bailding accounts which bears the name of Abram among others, showing that Jews were employed. Thai every stated requirement of the place of Oniaa is fulfilled this site; and there connexions are bere mentioned as they have not been noticed hitherto.

The form of this settlement of Oniaa was, roughly, a right-angled triangle, the sqoere corner being formed by the north and east idea At the west aonte angle wae the entry to it, and at the south point was the enmmit with the temple. The monnd was enclosed on the eastern side by a stone wall,. Soft or more in height, and 767ft. long, inolnding two bastioos at the sods. In the middle of this a high raised stairway, .IIP. wide, led op to the entry ot the temple cort on the top. The north side ot the settlement was low, with a fortification wall bounding it. The diagonal west side was curved inward, and had a great revetment wall, at least 20ft. thick, tiling at an angle of 68ft. or more, to a height of over 63ft., where it supposted the tepple.

The entrance from the plain at the west end was nearly 130ft. wide over all, and about 100ft. inside. This was fortified with towers and gateways, u we know Irom descriptions. From bere the way ran through to area of three or f or acres of booses enclosed in the fortifications leading up to the sample platform more than 68ft. over the poir. The foundation of this ascent remains, and points very closely to the axis of the court on the top. The outer court was 38ft. wide and 45ft. long inside, the inner court was 94ft wide end 64ft long. The block of the brick foundation of the Holly if Holies is 55ft long and 17f. wide. This is of the tame proportion u in Solomon's temple namely, 7 to 8 ; and it Howie that the building was Lid on with half the number of cubits of the prototype, end by the Greek cobit which was probably the most familiar to the Jews coder the Ptolemies. The architecture Corinthian ; and the front of the courts. or Of the temple, had the use of Syrian decoration of roanded battlements. The fronts these battlemenuts were ornamented with a band of lines, which rore from the string course into each block and returned.

The religious character of the whole place is marked by the great quantity of sacrifies at its foundation. In, the lower part of the mound are found on a couple of cylinders of pottery, a couple of feet across. There were took in the grdondre fin sacrifice was beret in each, and then the frach earth was thrown in to smother the; fire, to continuation of the beapirg the mound. This is it one with the Syriao sacrifices coder a bailding and the later form of that known as "lamp and jar burial," familiar In tn Mr. Macalister's work in Palestine.

Most unhappily. the ravagos of the natives digging for earth have barely left the outline of the foundationd of the temple : but 90 yeard ago the walls were stending, and the pavement end pillards were seen here. It is also stated that there was an immense mass of burnt bones, thrown out on the north of the town, which were very probably the remains of the daily burnt offering, long since utilized by speculators in phosphates. Such a loss of an historical building, owing to not recording the remains before their destruction, is an object- lesson in the need of thorough research in Egypt The work will not wait, and every help given to present laboors saves what will soon be irrecoverable ; contributions for this purpose should be sent to the secretary of the "British School I Egypt", at University College, London.

div.head: THE STAVRIOTES AND THE PORTE.
div.p: A correspondent of the "Daily News" writes thus from Coatantinople :

"A curious little incident has arisen in Turkey which is not without interest In the far east corner of the Black Sea there exists a people called Lazes, who have often been described as the descendants of Greek settlers dating from the time of the Xenophon expedition. Whether this is go or no Ftire Lazes appear to be of Greek blood. They are a stalwart race, and most of them profess Mahomedanism. But, as in the case of so many peoples thronghont the Tarkieh Empire, they accepted Islam when the condition was Islam or death.

"Among them are a considerable number who, while outwardly professing the religion of Mahomed, have secretly continued to practise Christian rites and to be bnried with the ceremonies of the Orthodox Greek Choroh. These people are known as Stavriotos, or Children of the Cross. Within the la"t month two priests were exiled because they conducted funeral eervioes over two Stavriotes, the local Governor declaring that the men were Moslems, and that Christian ceremonies were not permissible.

"When the exile of the two priests was reported to the Patriaroh here he took up the matter very seriously, and sent a protest to the Prte in very strong terms. I have not seen it, but an informant who has tells me that he doubts whether the chief cf any charoh in Tarkey ever sent a stronger one. It is not difficult to see that powerful arguments could be added by him showing that religions liberty to all subject of Turkey has been repeatedly flaunted in the eyes of Europe. . The matter made so little progress that on Satarday, ths 3rd lost, the Patriaroh declared that if the Porte did not ooosply with his demands he would refuse to celebrate Holy Communion in a church yesterday where he had promised to officiate.

"I am assured that be received a message from the Palace which concerened some of his demands, and as a matter of fact, he did celebrate yesterday in the church where be had promised to efficiate tyevious to his message. Had he refused to officiate, there would have at once bean an outory through all the Orthodox Churches in the world and the porte is wise in not allowing the question to become a serious one."

div.head: LONDON COMMERCIAL REPORT.
div.p: London, March 8.

Gux Arabic.—Buisness in Bombay kinds has been very quiet in the continoed absence of supplies, hot there is a lair inquiry, particularly for Ghletti. div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB
div.p: March Skye Meeting

The racing season at Alexandria opened on Saturday under auspicious circnumsatances. The club's March Skpe Meeting, though posturing no particular interest frem a racing standpoint, was very well attended, and from a social point of view at least wsd a success.

The weather was if anything too warm. The first khamseen of the season would have made it unpleasantly so bad it not been for a cool breeze which prevailed all the afternoon and which, after sunset, made it distinctly cold. The warm weather brought a large namber, of the fair sex wearing Tight spring frocks,, and their presence lent animation and colour to the scene.

As for the races, there is not much to be said. The entries were poor and the events almost devoid of interest. The best race of the day was perbaps the Nile Plate, in which Petrone won a well contested race from Doughan Three of the six events went to Ibrahim 'Bey Chard, while two were secured by Khalil PicbaKhayat, the sixth going to Boron J. & de Menasoe, who deserved his viotory. The Omdorman Plata was a Walk over for Gladiateur. The following are the particular the races.

MAHMOUDIEH PLATE of P.T. 2,000. via: P.T- 1.60" to winner and P.T. 400 to 2nd horse. For Arab ponies that have never won stokes or place money of the advertised gross value of L.E. 20. Weight for age and inches. Distance 5 furlongs.
Khalil Pacltica Khayat's ch.a.p. Doughan, 10.2 Jenkins.
Saleh Bey Yaghen's c.a.p. Acile, 10 2. White- side.
Ibrahim Bey Cheril's g.a.p. Ter ol Hamam, 10.7.
Ibrahim Bey Kheir g.a.p. Amour, 10 7.
Harsan Bey Khcir El Din's g.a.p. Mackboul, 10.2. Megehed,
Doughan jumped off and made all the running, winning easily by two lengths. Acile got up in the last stride and made a bid for seoond place, defeating Tor el Hamam.
Totalisator paid P.T. 38 on winner, and P.T. 26, 22, and 24 for places.

ABOUKIR STAKES of P.T. 1,500 viz 1,200 to winner and P.T. 300 to 2nd hourse. For Arabs that have never won stakes or place money of the advertised gross value of L.E. 20. Wright for age. Distance ¾ mile. Ibrahim Bey Cherifs' br.a.b. Chendi, 10.7. Michaelides Jun. Mr. E. Bustros' b.a.h. Dynamite, 10.6. Stillwell.
Saleh Bey Yaghen's a.h. Tokar. 10.7. Khalil Pacha Khayat's ch.a.h. Selman, 10.7 Jenkins.

Tokar jumped off to a good start and made the running till the cutting was reached when he gave way to Dynamite, who entered the straight first and looked like winning but was soon overtaken by Chendi. The two races almost abreast tillreaching the grandstated, when Chendi drew forward and won a good race by two lengths. Dynamite could not stay the distance and ceded second place to Voltigeur.
Totaliator paid P.T. 183 on winner and P.T. 28.28 and 31 for place.
THE NILE PLATE of P.T. 1.250 viz: P.T. 1,000 to the winner and P.T. 250 to 2nd horse. For Arab ponies. Weight for age and inches with penalties. Distance round the course.
Baron J. E. de Menasce's g.a.p. Petrone, 9.7. Matthews.
Khalil Pacha Khayat's c.a.p. Doughan, 9.8. Jenkins.

Mr.E. Karam's ch.a.p. Val d'Or II, 9.7 Elia. Ibrahim Fey Cherif's b.s.p. St. Fruaquin, 9.7. St. Fruaquin made all the running till the mile post, keeping about five lendths ahead of Val d"or. Nearing the cutting Val d'Or joined issues with the leader. Coming out iif the cutting however, it was seen that both had fallen back, Douhan and Petrone emerging first. The pair had a neck and neck race down the straight, Petrone finallu winning by a neck. The others were nowhere.
Totalizer paid P.T. 112 on winner and P.T. 37 ad 35 for places.
OMDURMAN PLATE of P.T. 1,000. For Arab. Weight for agee with penalities. Distance rooud the course. Ibrahim Bey Cherif's ch.a.h. Gladiateur, 9.7.
MAIDBN PONY PLATE of P.T. 1,250 of which P.T 250 to go to 2nd horse. For Maiden Arab ponies Weight for age and inches. Distaroe ¾ mile.
Khalil Pacha Khayt's g.a.p. Loulou, 10.3. 1 Ibrahim Bey Chet g.a.p. St. Feusquin,10.7. 2 Ibrahim Bey Chérif's g.a.p. Ter E1 Hamam, 10.7.
Hossan Bey Kbeir el Din's ch.a.p. Loohao, 10.7.

Loulou jumped off at ths start and led the whole way rooud, never once being overtaken, and fiaally won by a length and a half from St Frequin.Ter el Haman was the same diatance behind, third. Totalizator paid P.T. 80 to winner, and P.T. 25 and 48 for places.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, 21 Mars.

Le taux de I'eeoompte libre à Londres, qui avait été porté avant hier à 3 5/8 pour cent, a été ramené hier à 3 ½. Apparemment l'augmon tation avait été déterminée par une cause tout h fiait transitoire. D'ailleurs, tout porte à croire que le loyer de l'argent ne tardera pas it snbir une réduction sensible après la liquidation de fin de mois, car les conditions de la situation monétaire sur les mprobés régulateurs euro péens vont toujours s'améliorant.

Au Stook Exchange, hier, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié à 90 1/2. L'Unifiée a haussé de 3/8 à 106 1/4. La National Bank est renseignée en réaotion de 1/8 b 28 1/8. La Dsïra a haussé de 1/8 à 18 S.S. L'Agriooles'est maintenue à 10. La Delta Light a baissé de 1/8. b 12 1/2.
A Paris, l'aotion Crédit Foncier Egyptien a regagné 2 francs à 799. La Banque d'Athènes a réagi de 1 franc à 151.
Notre marché des valeurs a montré, ce matin, nn peu plus d'animation que les jours précédents, et les transactions pratiquées ont été assez nombreuses

La National Bank s'est inscrite á 28 1/16 ; l'action nouvelle k 27 8/16. L'Agrioole, très ferme aux abords de 10, a clôturé à 9 15/16. La Béhéra a fléchi à 37 1/4. La part de fondateur Wardau Estate a avancé à 6 8/4—7.
L'action Immobilière a fait 392 ; la part de fondateur est remontée à 640. L'Improvements Corporation a fléchi k 4 5/8.
Les jouissances Eaux du Caire ont passé de 272 á 275 ; la part de fondateur Land Allot ment do 165 á 170. L'action est remontée au pair.
L'aotion Enterprise and Development a avancé b 12 1/8 ; la part de fondateur b 16 3/4. L'aotion Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux s'est maintenue b 4 1/4 ; la part de fondateur á 15.
Bon monvement sur la Brasserie dw Pyramides qui, de 140, a atteint 148 pour clôturer b 146. L'aotion ordinaire Khédivial Mail a baissé en olûtnre á 39 sh.
Les Omnibus du Caire ont avancé b 33 1/2— 34; les Automobiles b 8 1/2.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nongovich ont faibli b 16 8/4. Les Baehler ont olOturé b 5 18/16

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Estates, en bonne ten dan oe, ont avancé b 2 1/16 ; la part de fondateur b 13 5/8. Les Egyptian Markets ont olOturé b 24 sh. ; les Glymenoponlo b £1 1/2 ; 1es Oasis b 1 5/16 et les Egyptian Constructions b 1 5/8—11/16.

L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la National Bank of Egypt a été tenue aujourd'hui á 3 h. 30 p.m. au siège sooial au Caire. Les comptes de l'exeroice 1905 ont été approuvés et il a été décidé de distribuer un dividende de 16 sh. par aotion, soit 8 % sur le oapital.
L'assemblée extraordinaire, qui devait avoir lien aussitôt après, a été ajournée au 15 avril prochain, le nombre d'actions représentées n'atteignant pas le chiffre requis par les Statuts.
On ne tardera pas b connaltre les résolutions prises b l'assemblée générale ordinaire de l'Egyptian Ertates Co., qui a dit être tenue b Londres.
En attendant, on affirme que le dividende par action de oapital a été fixé b 8sh. et qu'il sera payé 15 sh. par part de fondateur. Uiie autre version dit 21 sh.

On sait qu'il y a 20,000 parts de fondateur. Après le paiement d'un intérêt cumulatif de 5 % aux aotionsde oapital, le prélèvement fait pou; la réserve, eto., le 65 % du restant des bénéfices revient, d'après les Statuts, aux actions et le 35 % aux parts de fondateur.

A l'assemblée générale de la Compagnie Frigorifique d'Egypte, tenue hier an siège rocîal au Caire, il a été décidé de payer, pour i'exerciœ 1905 on dividende de P.E. 20 par aotion et de reporter le solde disponible des bénéfices, soit L.E. 930, b I'exerciœ oourant. Ce dividende sera payé b partir du ler avril prochain.
On annonce que le Banco di Roma va porter son capital social de 30 á 40 millions de francs.
La nouvelle émission d'actions aura lieu á la fin du mois courant. Un droit de préférenco pour la souscription sera accordé aux actionnaires actuels.
Il se confirme que l'émission de la Cairo Blectrio Railways and Heliopolis Oasis Co. aura lieu le mois prochain.
M. Empain, un des promoteurs de l'entreprise, est attendu la semaine prochaine en Egypte pour le règlement de certaines questions de détail aveo le gouvernement.

Les actionnaires de la Fayoum Light Railways Co. sont convoqoés en assemblée générale ordinaire le 7 avril prochain, an siège social au Caire. A l'ordre du jour : rapport du conseil d'administration et présentation des comptes depuis le 1er Mars 1905 jusqu'au 28 février 1906 ; nomination d'administrateurs et de censeors, etc.
Los cours du coton sont arrivés en nouvelle hausse d'Amérique. Hier, le disponible a gagné 10 points, le Mai 12 et l'Octobre 8.
Les arrivages ont été de 26,000 balles contre 28,000.
Le marché de Liverpool est également en reprise.
Ici, le Mai, qui a fini hier soir b 20 9/32, a ouvert ce matin á 20 5/16 pour clôture; á 20 3/8.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
